grounding: This article reviews a framework for studying the aggregation and propagation of microeconomic shocks in general equilibrium. We discuss the determinants of aggregate measures of real economic activity, like real GDP, real domestic absorption, and aggregate productivity in both efficient and inefficient environments. We also discuss how shocks from one set of producers are transmitted to other producers through prices and quantities. The framework we provide is amenable to generalization and can be used to study any collection of producers ranging from one isolated producer to an industry consisting of heterogeneous producers to an entire economy. We conclude with a brief survey of some of the applied questions that can be addressed using the analytical tools presented in this review and avenues for future work.
generated_text: This study investigates the interplay between micro-level propagation and macro-level aggregation in production networks, focusing on their impact on aggregate productivity and resource misallocation. By analyzing firm-level data and industry linkages, we develop a novel framework that bridges the gap between microeconomic shocks and macroeconomic outcomes. Our findings reveal that sector-specific disturbances can propagate through production networks, leading to significant comovement across industries and amplifying aggregate fluctuations. We demonstrate that the structure of these networks plays a crucial role in determining the extent of shock propagation and its effects on overall economic performance. Furthermore, our research highlights how resource misallocation at the micro level can accumulate and manifest as substantial productivity losses at the macro level, emphasizing the importance of efficient resource allocation in fostering economic growth.
